title: 107_hr940
content: The Act titled "Workplace Goods Job Growth and Competitiveness Act of 2001" includes a statute of repose for durable goods used in a trade or business. The "Workplace Goods Job Growth and Competitiveness Act of 2001" includes a provision that limits civil actions against manufacturers or sellers of durable goods for property damage or personal injury arising from accidents that occurred more than 18 years after the goods were delivered, provided the injury does not involve toxic harm and the claimant has received or is eligible for worker compensation. The "Workplace Goods Job Growth and Competitiveness Act of 2001" limits civil actions against manufacturers or sellers of durable goods for property damage or personal injury occurring more than 18 years after delivery, excluding toxic harm. Exceptions include transportation vehicles for hire, express warranties longer than 18 years, aviation limitations, and actions involving the environment. This Act preempts and supersedes any State law that establishes a statute of repose to the extent such law applies to actions covered by this Act. Any action not specifically covered by this Act shall be governed by applicable State law. The Act allows claimants to bring civil actions within 1 year of its enactment, even if another provision of law applies. The Act defines "claimant" as any person bringing an action covered by the Act, including the claimant's decedent or legal guardian if brought on their behalf. It also defines "durable good" as a product with a life expectancy of 3 or more years, used in a trade or business. The term "State" includes any State of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other territories or possessions. Goods can be used in a trade or business, for income production, or donated for various purposes. SEC. 4. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICATION OF ACT. This Act will take effect upon enactment, regardless of when the damage or injury occurred. It does not apply to civil actions initiated before enactment.
